That's one of Build's faults if anything. It's got the hallmarks of a show that would be popular with the West. But Kamen Rider and tokusatsu at large is a lot more than Build-style shows. ***READ THE GUIDE***

THE GUIDE: http://gunpla.buyfags.moe/

***READ THE GUIDE***

For those new to gunpla/plamo or even just new to this thread; please read the guide. Please read it before asking questions, as there is a chance it has already been answered there.

For those unfamiliar, "plamo" is a shortened form of "plastic model". If it's made of plastic, someone can probably help you here!
If you're new, you're gonna fuck up. Don't worry! If you're experienced, don't make the new people worry!

And remember to report any shitposting and spam to keep the thread clean and civil.

>Why won't anyone answer my question?
Try being specific, especially about your materials and process. Post images whenever possible; even if the kit/part looks bad, you are more likely to get help posting images.

>Why are my pictures sideways?
4chan strips EXIF data from images when they're uploaded to the site from your phone, including the orientation display tag. To fix this, save your images separately, or use an app that will rotate and save the images for you.
One commonly used app that works well on Android:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.simplemobilephotoresizer

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
it's one of the worst turret designs I have ever seen. It's attached to the hull with a mere metal plate with nothing to support it structurally wise. And the main gun is positioned in such a way that it would have been outright impossible to load any shells into it. The machine guns, despite their mountings are effectively coaxial MGs because the way the ammo belts are loaded into them limits the traverse. And last but not least it possesses no optics, and the only ones visible are mounted on the hull, effectively limiting the Vanagandr's environmental awareness to directly in front of it.

Overall, neither do I understand why the Feds kept it as their main AFV, it's such an incompetent design it would have worked better as a Republican vehicle. I have a hard time believing that the same nation that designed the Lowe designed this. The Vanagandr IMO should have just been a manned version of the Lowe, with a different paintjob and more blocky design, not this demonic mechanical spider from hell.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Why isn't mecha that much popular like in the 70s/80s/90s anymore?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21288434
no one expects serious answer or theories.
anyway
I think it's just time and technology issue.
during 70-90s technology was mostly understood to some point. people felt progression, and overall improvement of their lives and lives around them
that transferred into hopes and dreams of giant robots since they represent technology.
However times changed.
during 00 and 10, technology became too mainstream and too complicated for non-entusiasts to follow. people's hands were full trying to realise what is going on period right now, instead of hoping for better tomorrow. Some started to realize that technology is not a magical solution.
2020 comes around, we have technology ruining lives, jobs, more ecosystems, it's less understood than ever thanks to crypto/ai shit. People scared shitless of it already.
Therefore there is no hope for giant robots nor interest since they represent technology.
outside of niche genre sci-fi setting it always was.
So no, it's won't be popular as a mecha genre anymore. outside of long standing franchises.
Look at Musashi. It did everything correctly, and still no one in japan cares about it.
Shit sucks. we deserve it.

That's the RX-78-1
The one Amuro piloted in the original series was the RX-78-2. In the original canon there was only one more produced, the RX-78-3 which was never fully assembled and its parts were used to maintain the RX-78-2. But later additions to the canon in the form of side-stories, MSV, and video games have added the 4 through 6 as well as the Ground Gundams and Thunderbolt.

The RX-78-1 was the prototype, the 2 was supposed to be the test type and the 3 was supposed to be the completed combat model.

Back in the 90s is where the Ver Ka craze started among the garage resin kit makers. A company called Studio Reckless made their name by making Ver Ka resin Gundam kits, even though Katoki had no involvement with them at all. B-club, the resin kit department of Bandai back then, started getting Studio Reckless to make B-club kits of their Ver Ka designs. Bandai figured out from those early kits selling well that Katoki's name could help sales with their more mainstream models and toys, so they eventually started the "Gundam Fix" action figures and they brought Katoki onboard to let him design in his own way, and they also created the Ver Ka line of Master Grades.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21287369
AVS, canonically, links the pilot's brain to the machines computer. The result of this is the computer acting like an addition part of the pilot's brain, so what the computer knows the pilot knows as well. The sensors picked up the incoming shots, so Mika and Guts knew about them as well. Same thing with the machines telling them where to shoot.

There's also lore about how during the Calamity War, Gundam pilots mostly acted as bait. They'd draw the mobile armors to more isolated locations and keep them there while they were shot with danslief from a safe distance (like space. Just look at Hashmal's excavation). Being able to dodge a danslief shot was seen as a sign of a skilled pilot (though, this has a lot to do with their AVS being more powerful and augmenting the performance of it's pilots more than what we see with Tekkadan bar Mikazuki when he turns the safety limiter off).

last_replies.com:
>>21285367

> It's kinda implied that wanting to pilot the Gundam because it's the famous hero mech is a childish thing that only Kou and Monsha were being shitty brats about.

This is kind of dumb. Neither of them want to pilot the Gundam because "it's the famous hero mech" for a start, and Kou wants to pilot it because it's a better machine than something like a GM while both Kou and Monsha have attached their ego to piloting it in different ways. The second part might be childish, but both neither is predicated on the Gundam being a hero machine.

>>21287623

> Burning is a good combat pilot, but anyone would need time to adjust to the Gundam

People really overplay the importance of familiarity, though usually in reference to why Char lost a particular fight in the original show; so at least this is a new variation on the theme. That said though, a new military unit is not going to have radically different controls to previous generation units and while it might have a few new buttons, panels and greater performance, it's not something you need months of practice to familiarize yourself with. Gato was fairly comfortable with the GP-02 right off the bat for one, and that was built for a completely different faction and aesthetic than he's trained with.

A pilot experienced with a particular machine might know it's exact limits and be able to exploit it in ways someone green with it couldn't, but that does not mean someone new to it is just going to be stumbling around like a fawn. The performance increase a unit like the GP-01 would offer over the GM Custom Burning used would more than offset any problems lack of familiarity with the unit might cause an experiened pilot like Burning.

>>21261142

I find this to be a weird take because if the antagonist is supposed to be the one you're rooting for then...why aren't they the protagonist in the first place? A protagonist just being the character a story follows, and not inherently tied to the character's morality, personality, goals etc. at all. A protagonist does not need to be a "meek good guy", and I wouldn't describe any of the previous Gundam protagonists beyond perhaps Al as that anyway. I definitely wouldn't describe Amuro, Kamille or Judau as "meek" for one, even if they're "good guys".

If the audience is supposed to be rooting for the highly motivated antagonist and not the poorly motivated protagonist though, then the antagonist is the more interesting character and the story should be following him because he's the more interesting character who is doing more interesting things. If you want a reason why more stories don't do things like that then it's probably because more stories follow the interesting character, whether they're a good guy or not, and not the less interesting one. The antagonist is often cooler in a lot of stories, but usually isn't notably more interesting; though then again, I'd say the same is broadly true of Gato. I say broadly, because while I can certainly see why someone would think he's cooler, I definitely don't think he's interesting. I don't think any of 0083's cast are interesting though. Gato's coolness is very superficial too, beyond even that of someone like Char.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: People always say that humanoid mecha would never work in real life due to the square–cube law. So how would a 20-50 m tall robot need to look like to actually work IRL? It couldn't be based on real animals since even T-Rex only went up to 12 m.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21236610
You could trivially take out the biggest dinosaur with a 30mm autocannon or a 20mm Vulcan. So the same weakness as a (plausible with modern materials) mech. The problem isn't that large mechs are physically impossible, the problem is them being militarily unviable. You're making something tremendously bigger than a tank with much less armor than a tank (if you want it to move faster than a plot of a filler episode), and it can't move as fast as a plane (in atmosphere at least).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Mech's can only work if the work that you can do or what a typical animal can do is 1:1.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21236596
SCL aside, you'd also need a very strong motor that can reach at least 19200 RPM while having an adequate braking system that won't burn out from all the friction it'll have to take and can do so while carrying up to 380 tons. Otherwise, it'll be completely impractical.

threads.com:
***READ THE GUIDE***

THE GUIDE: http://gunpla.buyfags.moe/

***READ THE GUIDE***

For those new to gunpla/plamo or even just new to this thread; please read the guide. Please read it before asking questions, as there is a chance it has already been answered there.

For those unfamiliar, "plamo" is a shortened form of "plastic model". If it's made of plastic, someone can probably help you here!
If you're new, you're gonna fuck up. Don't worry! If you're experienced, don't make the new people worry!

And remember to report any shitposting and spam to keep the thread clean and civil.

>Why won't anyone answer my question?
Try being specific, especially about your materials and process. Post images whenever possible; even if the kit/part looks bad, you are more likely to get help posting images.

>Why are my pictures sideways?
4chan strips EXIF data from images when they're uploaded to the site from your phone, including the orientation display tag. To fix this, save your images separately, or use an app that will rotate and save the images for you.
One commonly used app that works well on Android:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.simplemobilephotoresizer

Despite being a comedic series, I unironically was more invested in Carranger than I’ve been in any Sentai show in over a decade. It created its own insane world, gave that world rules, and let the story play out in that setting. It wasn’t modern Toku’s “dangle keys in front of your face” humor, a lot of the funny parts came strictly from the characters and their interactions. The villains still posed a viable threat, you still cared about the main cast, and you still get invested in the wild mythology of the show. I honestly can’t say there are many Sentai shows I was as invested in as Carranger.

last_replies.com:
>>21284798
The director did not change at the half way point. Imanishi was in charge of the show alongside Mitsuko Kase from the second episode, and had joint director status until Kase left after episode 6. Imanishi was involved in storyboarding from episode 2 as well, which is usually where directors make themselves most known during a production. The departure of Kase is probably what you're thinking of as the primary cause for the change in direction of the show, since Imanishi was now in sole control, but he'd been partnered with Kase from episode 2 as director.

Director:
Mitsuko Kase (eps 1-7)
Takashi Imanishi (eps 2-13)

Storyboard:
Kazuki Akane (eps 7, 11)
Mitsuko Kase (eps 1, 5, 8)
Shinichiro Watanabe (eps 3, 6, 10)
Takashi Imanishi (eps 2, 4, 9, 12-13)

threads.com:
What is the best way to download (or buy) Force Five material these days?
Specifically looking for their adaptation of Danguard Ace, because I can't find it anywhere online except for a few bootleg DVD stores and a couple of dead Youtube links.
Internet Archive hosts nearly everything else from the anthology (along with a truckload of other old dubs), but the only entries pertaining to their version of Danguard are recordings of the theme song and a scanned VHS sleeve.
One of the comments in pic related kinda makes me wonder if the bootleg BD author found some episodes of the elusive Hawaiian or Filipino english dubs, though it’s more likely that they just pinched lines from the 2013 re-dub films, had to source from tapes of highly varying quality/condition, or even re-recorded lines himself. Considering that Asuka The Disc Dog has a reputation for selling disks with missing or broken audio tracks such things wouldn’t be too surprising.

As for Danguard itself it’s a pretty great show from what I’ve seen through the aforementioned newer dub (fun MOTW action and adventures, good melodrama, crisp animation) and I’d like to have some kind of an alternative to the ARR subs, in case they’re just as bad as some of the group’s other output.

I have no nostalgic attachment to any of these shows or dubs, I just happen to like a few 70s anime and also find the Yank dubs kinda interesting in terms of how well their source materials survived the edits and low-rent voice acting.

While I’m at it, what are your favorite ”pre-Akira” dubs of /m/-related media, be it for genuine quality/charm or just something to snicker at?
M&M Communication’s Mazinger Z is a pretty strong and faithful effort, complete with Isao Sasaki’s translated songs, and as a fan of ”dad jokes” I find ZIV’s second volume of Captain Harlock pretty funny at times. If I can’t laugh /with/ the jokes I'll at least have a hearty chuckle at the fact that it was an officially licensed mass-market tape.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21281804
The Streamline dub of Akira is usually referred to as the genesis of the "modern" anime dub, releasing long before companies like Central Park Media, VIZ, or Media Blasters started to set up shop. Prior to that anime dubs were typically heavily localized/trimmed down versions of shows resulting in things like Voltron or Astro Boy being seen as the standard for bringing over anime. One of the few exceptions to that was Robotech, or at least the Macross portion of it which still manages to be a fairly legitimate attempt to bring over an anime during the 80s.
